concepts.name: Sleep Fragmentation
concepts.description: The degree of disruption in sleep continuity, measured by nighttime awakenings and variability in sleep-wake cycles. In this study, it was associated with differential effects on memory and language, indicating domain-specific cognitive impacts.

concepts.name: Cognitive Heterogeneity
concepts.description: The observation that different cognitive domains (e.g., memory, language, processing speed) respond differently to the same sleep variable. This concept underscores the non-uniform nature of sleep-cognition relationships.

concepts.name: Daytime Activity Variability
concepts.description: The fluctuation in daily physical activity patterns, used as a proxy for behavioral regularity. High variability was linked to poorer visual-spatial and processing speed performance, suggesting rhythm stability supports cognition.

concepts.name: Objective Sleep Measurement
concepts.description: Use of wearable devices (e.g., actigraphy) to collect quantifiable, real-world sleep data. This method provides more reliable data than self-reports and was central to the study's validity.

concepts.name: Actigraphy
concepts.description: A non-invasive method using wrist-worn accelerometers to monitor movement and infer sleep-wake patterns. Used here to assess sleep duration, fragmentation, and light exposure over 8 weeks.

concepts.name: Longitudinal Monitoring Framework
concepts.description: A proposed research design for tracking sleep and cognition over time to detect early signs of decline. The study advocates for its use in preclinical Alzheimer’s detection.

concepts.name: Cognitive Reserve
concepts.description: The brain's ability to compensate for pathology through efficient neural networks. While not directly measured, the findings imply that stable sleep and activity patterns may support reserve maintenance.

concepts.name: Sleep Duration Paradox
concepts.description: The counterintuitive finding that longer sleep duration correlates with poorer language performance, suggesting excessive sleep may reflect underlying pathology or poor quality.

concepts.name: Neurocognitive Domains
concepts.description: Specific functional areas of cognition including memory, language, visual-spatial ability, and information processing speed. The study evaluated these domains to map sleep effects across cognitive systems.

concepts.name: Biological Marker
concepts.description: A measurable indicator of biological state or disease risk. The study proposes objective sleep and activity metrics as potential biomarkers for early cognitive decline.

concepts.name: Cross-Sectional Design
concepts.description: A study type that collects data at a single time point, limiting causal inference. This study used it due to baseline data from a clinical trial, but acknowledges its limitations.

concepts.name: Statistical Correlation
concepts.description: A measure of the linear relationship between two variables. Used here to assess associations between sleep parameters and cognitive scores after controlling for confounders.

concepts.name: Partial Correlation
concepts.description: A statistical technique that controls for the influence of one or more confounding variables. Applied to isolate the relationship between sleep and cognition while adjusting for covariates.

concepts.name: Pearson Correlation
concepts.description: A parametric test measuring linear correlation between two continuous variables. Used in the study to assess relationships between objective sleep metrics and cognitive scores.

concepts.name: Spearman Correlation
concepts.description: A non-parametric test assessing monotonic relationships between ranked variables. Applied when data did not meet normality assumptions, enhancing robustness of findings.

concepts.name: Confounding Variables
concepts.description: Factors that distort the apparent relationship between exposure and outcome. The study acknowledges uncontrolled variables like medication, diet, and comorbidities as key limitations.

concepts.name: Alzheimer’s Preclinical Stage
concepts.description: The phase before clinical symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease appear, where biomarkers may detect early neurodegeneration. The study positions sleep metrics as potential early indicators.

concepts.name: Non-Invasive Monitoring
concepts.description: Techniques that collect data without surgical or invasive procedures. Actigraphy exemplifies this, enabling long-term, real-world cognitive-sleep tracking in aging populations.

concepts.name: Sleep-Wake Cycle Stability
concepts.description: Consistency in timing and duration of sleep and wake periods. High variability was linked to cognitive decline, suggesting circadian regularity supports brain health.

concepts.name: Cognitive Decline Risk
concepts.description: The likelihood of developing measurable cognitive impairment over time. The study identifies sleep and activity patterns as modifiable risk factors for early detection.

concepts.name: REM/NREM Sleep Separation
concepts.description: The distinction between rapid eye movement and non-rapid eye movement sleep stages. The actigraphy device used could not differentiate these, limiting insight into stage-specific effects.

concepts.name: Neurodegenerative Prevention
concepts.description: Strategies aimed at delaying or halting the progression of diseases like Alzheimer’s. The study suggests sleep regulation as a potential preventive intervention.

concepts.name: Wearable Sensor Technology
concepts.description: Devices like actigraphy watches that collect physiological and behavioral data continuously. Used here to enable long-term, objective monitoring of sleep and activity.

concepts.name: Causal Inference Limitation
concepts.description: The inability to determine whether sleep patterns cause cognitive changes due to the cross-sectional design. A key methodological constraint acknowledged by the authors.

concepts.name: Statistical Power
concepts.description: The probability of detecting a true effect if it exists. The small sample size (n=17) severely limits power, increasing risk of Type II errors.

concepts.name: External Validity
concepts.description: The extent to which findings can be generalized to broader populations. The small, homogeneous sample limits generalizability beyond the studied cohort.

concepts.name: Cognitive Assessment Battery
concepts.description: A set of standardized tests measuring multiple cognitive domains. Used in the study to evaluate memory, language, visual-spatial ability, and processing speed.

concepts.name: Light Exposure Monitoring
concepts.description: Tracking ambient light levels via actigraphy to assess circadian entrainment. Included in data collection to explore light’s role in sleep-cognition dynamics.

concepts.name: Behavioral Regularity
concepts.description: Consistency in daily routines, including sleep and activity. High variability was associated with poorer cognition, highlighting its protective role.

concepts.name: Sleep Quality Index
concepts.description: A composite measure derived from actigraphy data reflecting sleep efficiency, duration, and fragmentation. Used as a key predictor in cognitive models.

concepts.name: Objective Biomarker Development
concepts.description: The process of identifying and validating measurable physiological indicators for disease risk. The study contributes to developing sleep-based biomarkers for cognitive health.

concepts.name: Clinical Trial Baseline Data
concepts.description: Data collected before intervention in a clinical study. This research used such data to conduct a secondary analysis on sleep-cognition links.

concepts.name: Information Processing Speed
concepts.description: The rate at which an individual can perform cognitive tasks. A key domain linked to activity variability and sleep quality in this study.

concepts.name: Visual-Spatial Ability
concepts.description: The capacity to perceive, analyze, and manipulate spatial relationships. Impaired performance was associated with irregular daily activity patterns.

concepts.name: Language Functioning
concepts.description: Cognitive processes involved in comprehension and production of language. Found to be negatively affected by longer sleep duration, suggesting a complex relationship.

concepts.name: Memory Performance
concepts.description: The ability to encode, store, and retrieve information. Positively correlated with sleep fragmentation, indicating a paradoxical relationship requiring further study.

concepts.name: Sleep-Wake Transition Variability
concepts.description: Fluctuations in the timing and stability of sleep onset and offset. A component of sleep fragmentation linked to cognitive outcomes in this study.

concepts.name: Circadian Rhythm Regulation
concepts.description: The biological process governing daily physiological cycles. Light exposure and activity patterns are key modulators, with implications for cognitive health in aging.

concepts.name: Modifiable Risk Factor
concepts.description: A characteristic that can be altered to reduce disease risk. Sleep and activity patterns are proposed as such factors for cognitive decline prevention.

concepts.name: Neurocognitive Assessment
concepts.description: Standardized evaluation of cognitive functions using validated tools. Used here to quantify performance across multiple domains in older adults.

methods.name: Actigraphy Monitoring
methods.description: Continuous measurement of movement and light exposure using a Philips Actiwatch Spectrum Pro device worn on the wrist for 8 weeks. Data were used to derive objective sleep parameters such as duration, fragmentation, and activity variability.

methods.name: Neurocognitive Battery Assessment
methods.description: A comprehensive set of standardized tests administered at baseline to evaluate memory, language, visual-spatial ability, and information processing speed. Scores were used as outcome variables in correlation analyses.

methods.name: Pearson Correlation
methods.description: A parametric statistical method used to assess linear relationships between continuous variables (e.g., sleep duration and language score), with adjustments for confounders via partial correlation.

methods.name: Spearman Partial Correlation
methods.description: A non-parametric approach used to assess monotonic relationships while controlling for covariates, particularly when data distributions were non-normal or ordinal.

methods.name: Cross-Sectional Analysis
methods.description: A study design analyzing data collected at a single time point to identify associations between variables (e.g., sleep and cognition), without tracking changes over time.

methods.name: Confounding Control
methods.description: Statistical adjustment using partial correlation to account for potential confounders such as age, sex, or comorbidities, though the study notes these were not fully measured.

methods.name: Data Collection Protocol
methods.description: Standardized procedures for wearing the actigraph and completing cognitive assessments, ensuring consistency in data acquisition across participants over the 8-week monitoring period.

methods.name: Objective Sleep Parameter Extraction
methods.description: Computation of sleep metrics (e.g., sleep efficiency, fragmentation index, duration) from raw actigraphy data using validated algorithms provided by the device manufacturer.

methods.name: Statistical Significance Testing
methods.description: Application of p-value thresholds to determine whether observed correlations were unlikely due to chance, supporting claims of meaningful associations.

methods.name: Baseline Data Utilization
methods.description: Use of pre-intervention data from an ongoing clinical trial to conduct a secondary analysis on sleep-cognition relationships without altering the original study design.

methods.name: Longitudinal Framework Proposal
methods.description: A methodological suggestion for future research involving repeated measurements over time to assess dynamic changes in sleep and cognition, enabling causal inference.

methods.name: Wearable Device Calibration
methods.description: Procedures to ensure accurate actigraphy readings, including proper device placement and adherence checks, though specific protocols were not detailed in the text.

methods.name: Cognitive Domain Scoring
methods.description: Standardized scoring of test results across memory, language, visual-spatial, and processing speed domains to generate composite scores for statistical analysis.

methods.name: Variable Transformation
methods.description: Application of rank-based or logarithmic transformations to normalize data distributions prior to correlation analysis, particularly for non-normally distributed variables.

methods.name: Data Integration
methods.description: Combining actigraphy-derived sleep and activity data with cognitive test scores to create a multimodal dataset for cross-domain analysis.

methods.name: Sample Size Justification
methods.description: Acknowledgment of the small sample size (n=17) and its implications for statistical power and generalizability, though no formal power analysis was reported.

methods.name: Causal Inference Limitation
methods.description: Explicit recognition that the cross-sectional design precludes causal conclusions, a methodological constraint highlighted in the discussion section.

methods.name: Biomarker Feasibility Assessment
methods.description: Evaluation of actigraphy metrics as potential non-invasive biomarkers for cognitive health, based on observed statistical associations.

methods.name: Domain-Specific Analysis
methods.description: Separate evaluation of sleep-cognition relationships within each cognitive domain (e.g., memory vs. language) to detect differential effects.
